poem:
**Orchestral Tapestry**

In Oramo's tapestry, heartstrings weave,  
Threads of Coleridge-Taylor softly cleave.  
Variations hum beneath bows' gentle sweep,  
Fragments of sound where our secrets sleep.  
Each note a leaf in autumn's embrace,  
In concert's garden, they find their place,  
Plain-speaking whispers, big-hearted, aware,  
In sonic echoes, we breathe shared air.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "BBC Symphony Orchestra/Oramo/Tetzlaff review – plain-speaking, big-hearted fare After 12 years at the helm of the BBC Symphony Orchestra, Sakari Oramo can be forgiven for programming seemingly disparate works simply because they are close to his heart. None were what you’d call standard repertoire, and each posed different challenges, yet somehow this multifaceted concert added up to more than the sum of its parts. Samuel Coleridge-Taylor’s Symphonic Variations on an African Air is one of". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
